Topic.Title: Nvidia is taking big risks moving into game hardware. Is it crazy or genius?

Message.Msg: A few of the "rave reviews" about the toy Shield that ibbey somehow missed posting. "Nvidia has pretty much lost out to Advanced Micro Devices in the race to supply chips to next-generation consoles. In that respect, Nvidia has made this business decision from a weak position, too, but it also has nothing to lose. Nvidia has probably lost some trust among its partners and customers. How do they know that Nvidia won’t compete head-on with them? The tough challenge for Nvidia will be marketing since it has very little elbow room in a crowded market. Rivals such as PowerA (the maker of the Moga controller) and Green Throttle Games (the creator of an upcoming Android game controller) will be selling their products for a lot less. How will Nvidia convince customers to pay a lot more for its device? JJ Richards, the head of marketing on PowerA’s Moga mobile-gaming controller marketing team, doesn’t think adding the screen to a controller will add much value, and he notes that it entails a lot of cost. The challenge is that Nvidia is going into areas where it has little experience, such as mass-market customer support and heavy-duty marketing. Nvidia also lacks the kind of design expertise that makes consumers lust after a new tech product. Some observers have reacted with disdain to the system’s design and wondered why it has a tablet that can’t be detached. If Nvidia gets one aspect of the design wrong, you can bet a competitor will get it right. One of the key features of Tegra 4 is its support for 4K video and 4K games. But there is very little 4K content out there. This feature adds costs, but it may not gain any new customers for Nvidia. Anand Shimpi, the head of tech analysis site Anandtech, said... he isn’t so sure that Android developers are up to the challenge of producing mobile games that people really want to play on a TV. And if there is no killer content for Nvidia, then the Project Shield system will fail. And what about the fact that the system can play titles from Valve’s Steam digital distribution service? Valve itself is expected to launch its own Linux-based open game console, dubbed the Steam Box. If that box takes off... at some point, Valve’s success means Nvidia’s failure." Maybe Jen will ship the toy Shield with one game pre-loaded? "Final Doom" would be appropriate.

Topic.Title: Project Shield Price-My Guess $299

Message.Msg: $399 is too expensive. Maybe $349 bundled with a blockbuster game or with a $50 off with a top end gamer discrete card. But $299 with no bundles it will sell well. A tie end with Gamestop stores would be an added benefit. Forget Walmart and Best Buy. This is a gamer add on and needs to marketed to them. Maybe later on for the full retail experience. JMHO

Topic.Title: Just in boys. Next generation iPads and IPad Minis coming in March.

Message.Msg: "Apple's iPad lineup is now on a twice-a-year refresh cycle, according to a new rumor, which pegs both the full-size iPad and iPad mini as due for updates in March." Oh my! My my my. Sales of those android devices will get Crushed twice a year now. Rather than just once. I'm sure that Wall Street will make the proper revisions to nvidia's estimates. To reflect this important change by Apple. Chop! chop! chop! chop!

Message.Title: anyone else underwhelmed by recent apple iphone commercials?
Message.Msg: There was a time when apple's iphone commercials would leave me speechless and amazed at this innovation or that new twist or whatever. lately, however, apple's commercials have been featuring some pretty #$%$ themes: -panoramic camera? wow. big f*cking deal. -caller do not disturb setting . again, big f*cking deal. those are just the two most recent ones that come to mind. what i haven't seen is a commercial bragging about their map app or anything that isn't already being done(and done better) on an android phone. it is a simple, sad fact in technology, as in life, that all things are cyclical. waxing and waning. up and down.

Topic.Title: anyone else underwhelmed by recent apple iphone commercials?

Message.Msg: Broke down and bought the girlfriend an Ipad 3 for christmas. Its what she wanted. Now all I hear is "I can't see this and I can't see that ". Because its in Flash. Then when trying to download I get "Flash is not supported on your device." What a pain in the #$%$.

Topic.Title: Apple Steals Throne from Android : Number One in U.S.A.

Message.Msg: "Apple’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) iOS was the majority smartphone platform in the U.S. for the first time ever, taking a 53.3 percent share for the four-month period ending November 25, according to data from the Kantar Worldpanel. It had a 35.8 percent share in the same quarter last year. “Apple has reached a major milestone in the U.S. by passing the 50-percent share mark for the first time, with further gains expected to be made during December, Kantar’s Dominic Sunnebo said in a statement." A truly Impressive iMilestone for Apple. Apple’s iOS : THE Numero Uno (#1) smartphone operating system, on the Planet. Because, well, it's the Best.

Message.Title: "Microsoft Eyes 3 New Surface Tablet Servings for 2013"
Message.Msg: "Microsoft Eyes 3 New Surface Tablet Servings for 2013" "Three new Microsoft Surface tablets are reportedly set to be unveiled later this year, joining the first batch that the software giant had simultaneously launched with the Windows 8 in October 2012. The fresh Microsoft devices will, of course, represent upgrades of the initial mobile hardware attempt from the company, which according to analysts had generally failed to achieve even the modest goals earlier outlined by Microsoft chief executive Steve Ballmer. Citing reports from a source identified only as MS_Nerd, BGR News said that Microsoft plans to rollout three variants of the Surface slate beginning Q4 2013, all sporting three different screen sizes that purportedly will cater to specific target markets. Most notable of the planned release is the 8.6-inch Surface RT 2, which will do away with the Nvidia Tegra chip that used with the first iteration. This new Surface RT is set to be deployed with Qualcomm chipset. Already in the Microsoft hardware pipeline too is the Surface Book, a hulking tablet with a 14.6-inch screen display that will rely on Intel's 22-nanometer Haswell chip for its processing power. The 2013 Microsoft Surface thrust will be completed by the 11.6-inch Surface Pro, which according to MS_Nerd will be powered by AMD's Temash APU. Note that this Surface Pro is different from the 64-bit tablet PC with a Core i5 processor that Microsoft said will hit global markets early this year." source: auDOTibtimeDOTcom
